title: How to Make a Zorro Mask

steps.headline: Cut a 5½-inch (13.97-centimeter) wide strip of black fabric.
steps.description: Cut the strip down the width of the fabric. Depending on the bolt, the strip will end up either 44 to 60 inches (1.12 or 1.52 meters) long. Use a soft, non-fraying fabric, such as jersey or flannel.

steps.headline: Drape the make over your face and feel where your eyes are.
steps.description: Find the center of the mask first, then drape it over your eyes. Make sure that the center of the mask is aligned with your nose. Once you have the mask centered, lightly trace your eyes with a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil. If you have a Styrofoam wig head, you can use that as a base instead.

steps.headline: Define the eyes.
steps.description: Spread the mask out on a flat surface. Use a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil to draw almond-shapes where the eyes are. Make the eyes smaller than you think they need to be; it is easier to cut away material than add it back.

steps.headline: Cut the eyes out.
steps.description: If you want to be more precise, cut just one eye out first, then fold the mask in half. Use the cut eye as a template for the second one.

steps.headline: Try the mask on, then make any adjustments.
steps.description: Zorro ties his mask behind his head, leaving long tails to trail down his back. The tails should reach your shoulder blades. Use a pin to mark off where you need to cut, then remove the mask and trim off the excess fabric. Make sure that you are cutting the same amount of fabric off of each end. The mask should be wide enough to cover your forehead and nose bridge. If it is too wide, cut it narrower. If you cut the eye openings too small, make them wider. Make sure that you don't expose your eyebrows.

steps.headline: Wear the Zorro mask.
steps.description: If you really want to get authentic, put a black bandana over your head first, with the bottom edge reaching the middle of your forehead. Wrap the mask around your eyes, then tie it in a knot at the back of your head. Place the mask's knot about the bandana's knot. This will help prevent it from slipping down.

steps.headline: Trace a mask shape onto a sheet of paper or cardstock.
steps.description: You can use a simple eye mask as a stencil, or you can print out a template from the internet. You can also draw a bean-shaped mask by hand. Make sure that it's long enough to cover your eyes and nose bridge, and wide enough to go from temple to temple.

steps.headline: Cut the template out, then test it against your child's face.
steps.description:
If you drew the mask by hand, use a pencil to mark out where the eyes should be. At this point, you should make any necessary adjustments:
If the mask is too big, cut it smaller. If the mask is too small, trace it again, but make it larger.

steps.headline: Use the template to cut your final mask out of black material.
steps.description: Place the template against a sheet of black felt or flannel. Trace around it using a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil. Put the template away, then cut the mask out. Don't forget to cut the eye holes out as well! You can also use black vinyl or faux leather instead.

steps.headline: Cut a strip of black elastic.
steps.description: The elastic needs to be long enough to stretch around the back of your child's head and each the sides of the mask while he or she is wearing it. Don't make the elastic too loose, however, or it won't stay on. Plan on using 7 to 9 inches (17.78 to 2286 centimeters) of elastic. You can also cut two long strips of black ribbon or vinyl instead of elastic. Plan on making each strip 20 inches (50 centimeters) long.

steps.headline: Pin the elastic to the sides of the mask.
steps.description: Turn the mask so that the back is facing you. Place each end of the elastic on each side of the mask. Make sure that the ends of the elastic are facing inwards (towards the middle of the mask) and not outwards. Pin them in place with sewing pins. The elastic should be overlapping the mask by about ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).

steps.headline: Sew the elastic down using black thread.
steps.description: It's best if you do this on a sewing machine, but you can do it by hand as well. If you are doing this on a sewing machine, be sure to sew up and down the elastic a few times so that it is nice and secure.

steps.headline: Add the mask to your child's Zorro costume.
steps.description: The elastic makes it easier for the child to take the mask on and off, without having to tie it. Best of all, if the child gets tired of wearing the mask, he or she can simply slide it down and let it dangle from their neck. If you used ribbon or vinyl straps, you will need to tie them in a bow behind the child's head.

text:
Making a Traditional Zorro Mask Cut a 5½-inch (13.97-centimeter) wide strip of black fabric. Cut the strip down the width of the fabric. Depending on the bolt, the strip will end up either 44 to 60 inches (1.12 or 1.52 meters) long. Use a soft, non-fraying fabric, such as jersey or flannel. Drape the make over your face and feel where your eyes are. Find the center of the mask first, then drape it over your eyes. Make sure that the center of the mask is aligned with your nose. Once you have the mask centered, lightly trace your eyes with a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil. If you have a Styrofoam wig head, you can use that as a base instead. Define the eyes. Spread the mask out on a flat surface. Use a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil to draw almond-shapes where the eyes are. Make the eyes smaller than you think they need to be; it is easier to cut away material than add it back. Cut the eyes out. If you want to be more precise, cut just one eye out first, then fold the mask in half. Use the cut eye as a template for the second one. Try the mask on, then make any adjustments. Zorro ties his mask behind his head, leaving long tails to trail down his back. The tails should reach your shoulder blades. Use a pin to mark off where you need to cut, then remove the mask and trim off the excess fabric. Make sure that you are cutting the same amount of fabric off of each end. The mask should be wide enough to cover your forehead and nose bridge. If it is too wide, cut it narrower. If you cut the eye openings too small, make them wider. Make sure that you don't expose your eyebrows. Wear the Zorro mask. If you really want to get authentic, put a black bandana over your head first, with the bottom edge reaching the middle of your forehead. Wrap the mask around your eyes, then tie it in a knot at the back of your head. Place the mask's knot about the bandana's knot. This will help prevent it from slipping down. Making a Child's Zorro Mask Trace a mask shape onto a sheet of paper or cardstock. You can use a simple eye mask as a stencil, or you can print out a template from the internet. You can also draw a bean-shaped mask by hand. Make sure that it's long enough to cover your eyes and nose bridge, and wide enough to go from temple to temple. Cut the template out, then test it against your child's face. If you drew the mask by hand, use a pencil to mark out where the eyes should be. At this point, you should make any necessary adjustments:
If the mask is too big, cut it smaller. If the mask is too small, trace it again, but make it larger. Use the template to cut your final mask out of black material. Place the template against a sheet of black felt or flannel. Trace around it using a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil. Put the template away, then cut the mask out. Don't forget to cut the eye holes out as well! You can also use black vinyl or faux leather instead. Cut a strip of black elastic. The elastic needs to be long enough to stretch around the back of your child's head and each the sides of the mask while he or she is wearing it. Don't make the elastic too loose, however, or it won't stay on. Plan on using 7 to 9 inches (17.78 to 2286 centimeters) of elastic. You can also cut two long strips of black ribbon or vinyl instead of elastic. Plan on making each strip 20 inches (50 centimeters) long. Pin the elastic to the sides of the mask. Turn the mask so that the back is facing you. Place each end of the elastic on each side of the mask. Make sure that the ends of the elastic are facing inwards (towards the middle of the mask) and not outwards. Pin them in place with sewing pins. The elastic should be overlapping the mask by about ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Sew the elastic down using black thread. It's best if you do this on a sewing machine, but you can do it by hand as well. If you are doing this on a sewing machine, be sure to sew up and down the elastic a few times so that it is nice and secure. Add the mask to your child's Zorro costume. The elastic makes it easier for the child to take the mask on and off, without having to tie it. Best of all, if the child gets tired of wearing the mask, he or she can simply slide it down and let it dangle from their neck. If you used ribbon or vinyl straps, you will need to tie them in a bow behind the child's head.
sentences: Making a Traditional Zorro Mask Cut a 5½-inch (13.97-centimeter) wide strip of black fabric.
Cut the strip down the width of the fabric.
Depending on the bolt, the strip will end up either 44 to 60 inches (1.12 or 1.52 meters) long.
Use a soft, non-fraying fabric, such as jersey or flannel.
Drape the make over your face and feel where your eyes are.
Find the center of the mask first, then drape it over your eyes.
Make sure that the center of the mask is aligned with your nose.
Once you have the mask centered, lightly trace your eyes with a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil.
If you have a Styrofoam wig head, you can use that as a base instead.
Define the eyes.
Spread the mask out on a flat surface.
Use a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil to draw almond-shapes where the eyes are.
Make the eyes smaller than you think they need to be; it is easier to cut away material than add it back.
Cut the eyes out.
If you want to be more precise, cut just one eye out first, then fold the mask in half.
Use the cut eye as a template for the second one.
Try the mask on, then make any adjustments.
Zorro ties his mask behind his head, leaving long tails to trail down his back.
The tails should reach your shoulder blades.
Use a pin to mark off where you need to cut, then remove the mask and trim off the excess fabric.
Make sure that you are cutting the same amount of fabric off of each end.
The mask should be wide enough to cover your forehead and nose bridge.
If it is too wide, cut it narrower.
If you cut the eye openings too small, make them wider.
Make sure that you don't expose your eyebrows.
Wear the Zorro mask.
If you really want to get authentic, put a black bandana over your head first, with the bottom edge reaching the middle of your forehead.
Wrap the mask around your eyes, then tie it in a knot at the back of your head.
Place the mask's knot about the bandana's knot.
This will help prevent it from slipping down.
Making a Child's Zorro Mask Trace a mask shape onto a sheet of paper or cardstock.
You can use a simple eye mask as a stencil, or you can print out a template from the internet.
You can also draw a bean-shaped mask by hand.
Make sure that it's long enough to cover your eyes and nose bridge, and wide enough to go from temple to temple.
Cut the template out, then test it against your child's face.
If you drew the mask by hand, use a pencil to mark out where the eyes should be.

At this point, you should make any necessary adjustments:
If the mask is too big, cut it smaller.
If the mask is too small, trace it again, but make it larger.
Use the template to cut your final mask out of black material.
Place the template against a sheet of black felt or flannel.
Trace around it using a white dressmaker's chalk or pencil.
Put the template away, then cut the mask out.
Don't forget to cut the eye holes out as well!
You can also use black vinyl or faux leather instead.
Cut a strip of black elastic.
The elastic needs to be long enough to stretch around the back of your child's head and each the sides of the mask while he or she is wearing it.
Don't make the elastic too loose, however, or it won't stay on.
Plan on using 7 to 9 inches (17.78 to 2286 centimeters) of elastic.
You can also cut two long strips of black ribbon or vinyl instead of elastic.
Plan on making each strip 20 inches (50 centimeters) long.
Pin the elastic to the sides of the mask.
Turn the mask so that the back is facing you.
Place each end of the elastic on each side of the mask.
Make sure that the ends of the elastic are facing inwards (towards the middle of the mask) and not outwards.
Pin them in place with sewing pins.
The elastic should be overlapping the mask by about ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).
Sew the elastic down using black thread.
It's best if you do this on a sewing machine, but you can do it by hand as well.
If you are doing this on a sewing machine, be sure to sew up and down the elastic a few times so that it is nice and secure.
Add the mask to your child's Zorro costume.
The elastic makes it easier for the child to take the mask on and off, without having to tie it.
Best of all, if the child gets tired of wearing the mask, he or she can simply slide it down and let it dangle from their neck.
If you used ribbon or vinyl straps, you will need to tie them in a bow behind the child's head.
